RTVF 551 MFA in Documentary Media: Documentary Techniques

Instructor: Debra Tolchinsky
debtolchinsky@northwestern.edu

Course Description and Objectives
In this course, students will be introduced to traditional small-crew documentary filmmaking through the process of directing their own short 6 to 8 minute project. Students will get hands on experience shooting, interviewing, recording sound and editing. Topics touched upon will include audience engagement, documentary innovation, and ethics.

Class time will be divided between watching and critiquing peer generated work, guest filmmaker visits and screenings/discussions of influential documentary films. By speaking with filmmakers and viewing documentaries by directors such as Sarah Polley, Werner Herzog, Frederick Wiseman and Joshua Oppenheimer students will wrestle with: What kinds of documentaries are relevant today? What are the ethical obligations of a documentarian? How do budgetary restrictions determine stylistic choice? How does stylistic choice interact with content?

Requirements: A series of written exercises including a one-page examination of the ethical considerations in a TBA documentary film, a project proposal, an on-camera interview, a rough cut, and a finished 6-8 minute documentary.
